title: VK RZ A1H: needs an update from RZ A1H (cmsis, rtos related)
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Priority: Major

### Bug

VK RZ A1H target requires an update. As it does not share the same codebase, but very identical implementation, it needs to be updated to be re-enabled. I fixed few errors there, and stopped at MMU and cache settings in the startup (cmsis updated their API, and RZ A1H changed few things in the startup) - as they become more difficult to fix.  As result, it was temporarily disabled for the release 5.7.2.

It would be much easier if they share as much common code as they could. As they don't, we either patch the current implementation, or start sharing the common one to get the updates from RZ A1H.

Related: https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/5770 - this one fixes some issues we found.

cc @TomoYamanaka @mbedNoobNinja Please review and help

title: Sending large payloads over PPPInterface socket fails
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug

## Bug

**Target**
Any target implementing PPPInterface

**Toolchain:**
All

**mbed-os sha:**
Mbed OS 5.7

When you create a request in [mbed-http](https://os.mbed.com/teams/sandbox/code/mbed-http/) it creates a buffer, which it then sends over HTTP. There is no streaming or anything involved, and as long as there's enough memory available that's fine. However... A user has found out that when you send a file larger than 1400 bytes over PPPInterface the request fails, as the UART buffer used to communicate with the cellular modem gets full. I believe that splitting the payload up should be done by the driver in this case, as I don't know the optimal buffer size. I think this is reproducable by just doing:

```
TCPSocket socket; // attach it etc.
char buffer[10000] = { 1 };
socket.send(buffer, 10000);
```

[Bug report here](https://os.mbed.com/questions/79712/mbed-OS-http_mbed-Cannot-http-PUT-payloa/?c=29176).

title: [WIP] attempt to use lp_ticker as main ticker source when it is possible
body:
## Description

After analyzing the us_ticker api usage, almost no driver is actually using high resolution timer.
The two highest frequencies being by default :
- 10KHz for BLE/Eddystone's urlTicker ;
- 20KHz for nanostack's hal's timer/timeout.

This PR aims at using lp_ticker as the default ticker.

## Status

**IN DEVELOPMENT**

## Migrations

After this PR is merge, *API users* may need to check their ticker usage in case they really need high resolution ticks

YES | NO

title: Added statvfs API to get storage statistics
body:
The API is as per posix standard, but does not provide stats for file/directory. Stats buffer (block size, total block count, free block count) is filled for mounted filesystem.

~Todo: Littlefs statvfs code~
CC @geky 

Related Issue: https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/5702

STM can_filter not filter right for using wrong mask bit
body:
Note: This is just a template, so feel free to use/remove the unnecessary things

### Description
- Type: Bug
- Related issue: 
- Priority: Major

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
STM32

**Description**
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/can_api.c
mask bit 0x00FF as code below  is wrong. Id and mask low part is 16bit.So it should be 0xFFFF
sFilterConfig.FilterIdHigh = id >> 13; // EXTID[28:13]
        sFilterConfig.FilterIdLow = (0x00FF & (id << 3)) | (1 << 2);  // EXTID[12:0]
            sFilterConfig.FilterMaskIdHigh = mask >> 13;
            sFilterConfig.FilterMaskIdLow = (0x00FF & (mask << 3)) | (1 << 2);
**Expected behavior**
filter should only receive message accroding to id and mask
**Actual behavior**
filter not working with cetain filter

Thank you very much,

title: EFM32: EM2 mode blocked when should not be
littlefs: Fix issue with immediate exhaustion and small unaligned storage
body:
This was a small hole in the logic that handles initializing the lookahead buffer. To imitate exhaustion (so the block allocator will trigger a scan), the lookahead buffer is rewound a full lookahead and set up to look like it is exhausted. However, unlike normal allocation, this rewind was not kept aligned to a multiple of the scan size, which is limited by both the lookahead buffer and the total storage size.

This bug went unnoticed for so long because it only causes problems when the block device is both:
1. Not aligned to the lookahead buffer (not a power of 2)
2. Smaller than the lookahead buffer (< 64 blocks)

While this seems like a strange corner case for a block device, this turned out to be very common for internal flash, especially when a handful of blocks are reserved for code.

note: intended for patch
cc @marcuschangarm

title: nanostack-hal: add alternative critical section implementation
body:
## Description
(This PR has the same content as https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os-confidential-m/pull/8)

The nanostack hal's critical section uses a mutex for mutual exclusion,
which is nice for many use cases. But when one needs to use the critical
section from interrupts, the RTX will have a assertion failure and panic.

Add a configurable for mbed_lib, which can be used to enable a alternative
version of critical section, which uses the underlying OS primitives, which
disables the interrupts.

Note: the default behavior is not changed, one needs to override the
"nanostack-hal.critical-section-usable-from-interrupt" to have "true".

Reason for this change is that there is a need for sending events using
nanostack event queue from interrupt context, eg. from a socket callback.

## Status

**READY**

## Migrations

YES | NO

## Related PRs

## Todos

- [ ] Tests
- [ ] Documentation

## Deploy notes

Note: this should not be the first and/or only fix, as it may cause troubles on drivers which can not tolerate delays on interrupt deliveries.

## Steps to test or reproduce

K64F with ESP8266, debug profile:
"Mutex 0x200017ec error -6: Not allowed in ISR context"

title: Update uVisor CI to use new GitHub plugin
K64F Ethernet: avoid using NULL thread during init
body:
The K64F Ethernet driver installs an interrupt handler that sets thread
flags, and this could be called before the thread was initialised, so it
would use a NULL thread ID.

This triggers an RTX error-checking trap in debug builds, and could also
lead to other problems with received packets not being processed.

Adjusted so the RX interrupt handler does nothing if the thread isn't
initialised yet, and manually trigger a RX event flag after initialising
the thread in case any interrupts were ignored.

An alternative would have been to implement eth_arch_enable_interrupts,
but this mechanism is not present in the EMAC world - drivers will have
to start returning interrupts in their power up.

Fixes #5680

title: Add us ticker bare metal test.
body:
## Description

Add us ticker bare metal test.

Requirements:

> When vendors start porting a platform to mbed OS, they need to take big steps before they actually can start running tests. One of the first requirements to run greentea is functional us ticker, unfortunately there's nothing that would tell whether the implementation is correct. This can assume working UART as proved in https://jira.arm.com/browse/IOTMORF-1244
> Analyse greentea to identify us ticker usecases that need to be tested to ensure the greentea will work correctly.
> Create tests set:
> it shouldn't use greentea
> can be run on minimal (not complete) mbed OS port
> doesn't use other part of the system except UART (to the extent validated in IOTMORF-1244)
> tests enough of us ticker to enable greentea
> doesnt need to be full unit/integration tests for us ticker

Files:
test.py - host part of the test. This script builds mbed part of the test and performs us ticker test.
main.cpp - source file for mbed part of the test to verify if us ticker driver is correctly implemented.

lib/BMComm.h - class which provides communication between host and device.
lib/BMTest.h - class which provides support for bare metal tests.

Example usage:

python test.py -t GCC_ARM -m NUCLEO_F070RBrun test using GCC_ARM toolchain and NUCLEO_F070RB board

python test.py -h - see detail usage information.

## Status

HOLD - test location needs to be changed

## Migrations
NO


## Todos

Change test location when the valid location for bare metal tests will be agreed.

title: Greentea wifi test cases - disconnect done as teardown after each connect
body:
## Description
Assumed behavior of the drivers is that when connect method is called the modem is not in connected state. In other words when a test case executes connect successfully the next case assumes that disconnect has also been called.

If AP is not found instead of expecting NSAPI_ERROR_PARAMETER we are expecting NSAPI_ERROR_NO_SSID from now on. 

NSAPI_SECURITY_WPA_WPA2 used in WIFI_CONNECT_SECURE from now on.

Don't check against assumed channel if user configures channel number as 0. This is helpful if a driver does not support setting the channel.

## Status

**READY**

## Migrations

NO

In tests-mbed_drivers-lp_timer, since low power timer is less accurate than regular timer,
there is a delta time based on CPU clock frequency.

For ex, STM32F7 has a system core clock set to 216MHz, then delta time is only 370us.

So we propose to set a kind of minimum delta time around 500us.

title: Add presentation format descriptor support for nRF5x
body:
Notes:
- Have agreed to contributor agreement on mbed site (user: dschuler)

## Description

Looking through the mbed BTLE sources, I can find the characteristic presentation format descriptor, BLE_UUID_DESCRIPTOR_CHAR_PRESENTATION_FORMAT, as well as a struct to hold the format in GattCharacteristic::PresentationFormat_t. However, when I add this descriptor to a characteristic and test using Nordic's NRF52 DK board, the descriptor does not appear.

Nordic seems to handle this presentation format differently from other descriptors, along with BLE_UUID_DESCRIPTOR_CHAR_USER_DESC. So, here I added a code path to handle the presentation format the similarly. Tested again on the NRF52 DK, everything appears to be working well.

## Status

**READY**

## Migrations

This does not change any APIs or behavior, but should allow a user to pass a characteristic presentation format descriptor, which was not possible before.

## Related PRs

No related PRs.

## Todos

- [ ] Tests
- [ ] Documentation

I will create another PR with sample code to use the characteristic presentation format.

## Deploy notes

Nothing needs to be done to deploy these changes.

## Steps to test or reproduce

To test if this PR works, create a descriptor of type BLE_UUID_DESCRIPTOR_CHAR_PRESENTATION_FORMAT - without these changes, the descriptor will not appear on a Nordic NRF52 target. I assume the NRF51 target will have a similar issue, but I had some unrelated probles getting the NRF51 dongle to work so can't currently test changes to NRF51.

title: Add memory barriers to STM32F7xx Ethernet
body:
Pending official update from STM, add memory barriers to the Ethernet
HAL code for the STM32F7xx family.

Cortex-M7 has a merging write buffer that is not automatically flushed
by accesses to devices, so without these DMBs, we sometimes lose synch
with the transmitter.

The DMBs are architecturally needed in every version of this HAL, but
adding just to the STM32F7 version for now to clear test, as the
problem has only been observed on Cortex-M7-based devices.

Fixes #5622.

title: Bug - SPI::abort_transfer() can decrement/unlock deep sleep manager lock without ever incrementing/locking it
body:
### Description

- Type: Bug
- Related issue: `#5716`
- Priority:  Minor

When transferring data using `SPI::start_transfer()` deep sleep mode is disabled by calling `sleep_manager_lock_deep_sleep()`. When the transfer is complete or aborted `sleep_manager_unlock_deep_sleep()` is called decrementing the lock count counter, and potentially re-enabling deep sleep mode.

The deep sleep manager tracks the number of locks acquired by device drivers, when `lock_deep_sleep()` is called the lock count is incremented, when `unlock_deep_sleep()` is called the count is decremented, while the `count != 0` deep sleep mode is disabled.

Each device driver should call `lock` and `unlock` as a pair of operations to prevent either decrementing/removing a different device drivers lock or locking deep sleep permanently. `SPI::abort_transfer()` can be called at any time and will unlock deep sleep mode regardless of whether SPI has previously locked it.

The SPI class should track whether or not it currently holds a lock in the deep sleep manager and only call sleep_manager_unlock_deep_sleep() if it does.


---------------------------------------------------------------
**Target**
All

**Toolchain:**
All

**mbed-os sha:**
`4d81eadb25a509d82d54439c5674843779d30470`

title: Bug - I2C::abort_transfer() can decrement/unlock deep sleep manager lock without ever incrementing/locking it
body:
### Description

- Type: Bug
- Related Issue: #5717
- Priority:  Minor

When initialising an `I2C::transfer()` the function will call `sleep_manager_lock_deep_sleep()`  to disable deep sleep mode while the transfer is in progress. When the transfer is complete via `I2C::irq_handler_asynch()` or aborted via `I2C::abort_transfer()` , `sleep_manager_unlock_deep_sleep()` is called decrementing the lock count counter, and potentially re-enabling deep sleep mode.

The sleep manager implements a counter which tracks locks and unlocks of deep sleep mode. Deep sleep is only enabled when the counter is 0. Because `I2C::abort_transfer` can be called without ever initialising a transfer, if the deep sleep is currently locked by a different device in the application, `abort_transfer` will decrement and remove the lock count added by a different device driver.

The I2C class should track whether or not it currently holds a lock in the deep sleep manager and only call `sleep_manager_unlock_deep_sleep()` if it does.

Example:

```c++
PwmOut led(LED1);
// PwmOut locks deep sleep mode, count = 1
led.write(0.5f);

I2C i2c(p28, p27);
// I2C unlocks deep sleep mode, count = 0
// Deep sleep mode re-enabled while PwmOut is running
i2c.abort_transfer();
```



---------------------------------------------------------------
**Target**
All

**Toolchain:**
All

**mbed-os sha:**
`4d81eadb25a509d82d54439c5674843779d30470`

title: Release candidate for mbed-os-5.7.0-rc3
Nucleo-L432KC Drag-and-Drop Programming of .bin files not always working
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug 
- Related issue: https://os.mbed.com/forum/bugs-suggestions/topic/28258/?page=1#comment-53688
- Priority: Blocker 

## Bug
**Target**
STM Nucleo-L432KC

**Toolchain:**
Mbed Online Compiler

**Toolchain version:**
mbed 2.0 Library Revisions 153,154,155,156,157 (Revision 152 seems OK)

**Operating system:**
Windows 8.1 fully patched

**ST-LINK, ST-LINK/V2, ST-LINK/V2-1 USB driver signed for Windows7, Windows8, Windows10**
USB Driver downloaded on 12/14/2017 from http://www.st.com/en/development-tools/stsw-link009.html
Drivers installed and PC rebooted on 12/14/2017.

**ST-LINK, ST-LINK/V2, ST-LINK/V2-1 firmware upgrade**
Latest firmware downloaded on 12/14/2017 from http://www.st.com/en/development-tools/stsw-link007.html.
Firmware installed using: STLinkUpgrade 3.2.2.
Firmware version: V2J28M18.
Board unplugged after reflash, re-inserted, firmware verified as V2J28M18.
Verified that only ONE Nucleo board is present on system, i.e. correct target is being flashed.

**Expected behavior**
Drag-and-Drop programming of .bin files generated by mbed online compiler to USB Mass Storage device "NODE_L432KC" should always work when correct compile target is being used (Nucleo-L432KC).

**Actual behavior**
Drag-and-drop programming does *not* always work.  Some .bin files are *not* flashed to the target.

**Steps to reproduce**
1. Select Nucleo-L432KC as target, and use online compiler to compile this code: https://os.mbed.com/users/nixnax/code/PPP-Blinky/ 

2. Attempt to save mbed-generated .bin file to target board's USB MSD drive named "NODE_L432KC".
The flash fails. The normal red/green LED flash sequence that occurs during flashing does not occur.

**Additional Information**
IF the first four bytes in the .bin file are changed (via hex editor) to 00 C0 00 20 then the .bin file can be successfully saved to the USB MSD, flashing appears to be successful and the code appears to execute correctly.  So the issue seems to be related to the first 32-bit word in the .bin file.

title: Statically allocate ARMCC required mutex objects
body:
This is fix for - https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/5664
Previously we used OS_MUTEX_NUM define to pre-allocate Mutex objects for ARMCC libs. But that doesn't guarantee that they will be avaliable for ARMCC usage always as any other client can grab them before ARMCC lib requires that to be used/initialized. This change is to statically allocate memory for Mutex objects for ARMCC to ensure ARMCC have them when it needs.

**Expected behavior**
`.link_files.txt` should never have duplicate file entries

**Actual behavior**
The following duplicated entries appeared in `.link_files.txt` 
```
C:\my-mbed-project\projects\test-json11\build\debug\.\json11.o
C:\my-mbed-project\projects\test-json11\build\debug\.\mbed_memory_status.o
C:\my-mbed-project\projects\test-json11\build\debug\.\test_env.o
[...]
C:\my-mbed-project\projects\test-json11\build\debug\json11.o
C:\my-mbed-project\projects\test-json11\build\debug\mbed_memory_status.o
C:\my-mbed-project\projects\test-json11\build\debug\test_env.o
```

**Steps to reproduce**
I invoked make.py directly using the following command (on MINGW64 / windows7):
```
[mbed] Exec "C:\Python27\python.exe -u C:\my-mbed-project\libs\mbed-os\tools\make.py -t GCC_ARM -m NUCLEO_F767ZI --profile C:\my-mbed-project\profiles\debug.json --source C:\my-mbed-project\projects\test-json11 --source C:\my-mbed-project\libs\mbed-memory-status --source C:\my-mbed-project\libs\json11 --source C:\my-mbed-project\libs\mbed-os --build C:\my-mbed-project\projects\test-json11\build\debug --app-config C:\my-mbed-project\projects\test-json11\mbed_app.json" in C:\my-mbed-project
```

Note that after a clean everything works fine, this issue only appears when then doing a second build.

I fixed this by adding
`path = abspath(path)` to the `scan_resources` function in `mbed-os\tools\toolchains\__init__.py`. Because the paths are now normalized the duplicated get filtered by `r.objects = sorted(set(r.objects))` in function `link_program`

Is this a bug or am I doing something horribly wrong?

body:
CRC class implementation

CRC class `BaseCRC.h` is created to support hardware/software CRCs

BitwiseCRC.h contains software CRC implementation for bitwise CRC computation which will be somewhat slow compared to other techniques as bit by bit computation is performed in software.

FastCRC.h contains software CRC implementation using lookup table method. Table is generated during init step.

HalfByteCRC.h constains software implementation for CRC32 using 16-entry technique to have limited table size (64bytes) and is fast compared to bitwise CRC computation. Table is generated runtime during init call.

Usage example:
https://gist.github.com/deepikabhavnani/0dacf5572c0b4d87b8fbfbcfd9246a95

title: STM32: mbed-cli with GCC_ARM does not include code for CAN_2 and CAN_3
body:
File [can_api.c](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/can_api.c) uses the following mechanism to include code for CAN2/CAN3:

```
#if defined(CAN3_BASE) && defined(CAN_3)
/* Code goes here */
#endif
```

This work perfectly for `CAN3_BASE` (which is a macro defined in the STM32 Cube HAL) but does not work with `CAN_3` (which member of an enum defined in target-specific `PeripheralNames.h`). This is probably because GCC doesn't consider enum members as "defined".

A quick hack to make this work under `GCC_ARM` is to manually add `-DCAN_3=CAN_3` to `mbed compile`, which is not very convenient.

A correct solution to rewrite the mechanism or look if there is a GCC flag (and possibly a flag for other compilers as well) which would make the `defined()` macro recognize enum entries.

title: STM32: Fix CAN3
body:
This fixes CAN3 for STM32 platforms. Checked with two NUCLEO-F413ZH boards (added in https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/5608).

I was not able to receive any data on STM32F413ZH. It was because the filter number 14 is not in the valid range for CAN3.

This restriction also holds for STM32F767ZI (checked in both RM0430 for STM32F413 and RM0410 for STM32F767), which has been originally used to test CAN3 in https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/5486.

Also, this PR sets correct indexes for interrupt handlers.

title: Add exporter for Analog Devices' CrossCore Embedded Studio
body:
Notes:
- Pull requests will not be accepted until the submitter has agreed to the [contributer agreement](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).

## Description

This pull request adds an exporter for Analog Devices' CrossCore Embedded Studio (CCES) Eclipse-based IDE (http://www.analog.com/en/design-center/processors-and-dsp/evaluation-and-development-software/adswt-cces.html#dsp-overview).

Currently only supports Analog Devices (ADI) targets:
- EVAL_ADICUP3029
- EV_COG_AD3029LZ
- EV_COG_AD4050LZ

## Status

**READY**

## Migrations

NO

## Related PRs

None.

## Todos

- [ ] Sign CLA

## Deploy notes

Requires CrossCore Embedded Studio 2.8.0 or newer to be installed (set to release in March 2018). 30-day evaluation licenses are available. Once installed, set CCES_HOME environment variable to point to the top level of the installation (i.e. "C:\Analog Devices\CrossCore Embedded Studio 2.8.0")

## Steps to test or reproduce

Export a project to CCES:
`mbed export -i cces -m EV_COG_AD4050LZ`
